I'd use `?callable` instead of `?Closure` to allow for invokable objects, and other callable (such as denoted by the array syntax).

```php
public function throw(?callable $callback = null)
```

P.S.: don't forget to update the docblock

Wow. I took another look at the code and was very surprised!

@jasonmccreary, okay, let's say `200` is the status code and `'204'` is the response body.

But what is the difference between, for example, `500` and `600`? Here `500` is the **status code**, and `600` is the **response body** ðŸ˜€

@taylorotwell, you'll be interested too (I wrote my thoughts above, and here's an addendum).

```php
Http::fake([
    'google.com' => 'Hello World', // no problem
    'github.com' => ['foo' => 'bar'], // no problem

    'bar.laravel.com' => '204', // it's a response body with status code 200

    'foo.laravel.com' => 99, // it's a response body with status code 200
    'foo.laravel.com' => 100, // it's a status code 100
    'foo.laravel.com' => 204, // it's a status code 204
    'foo.laravel.com' => 204.99, // it's a response body with status code 200
    'foo.laravel.com' => 599, // it's a status code 599
    'foo.laravel.com' => 600, // it's a response body with status code 200
]);
```
Yeah, you can do that too :)
Oh, I misread `ResponseSequence` as `Response` ðŸ¤¦ðŸ»â€â™‚ï¸ Your suggestion makes more sense then ðŸ˜…
